feed.title: Survivor Interview: Dawn Meehan and Whitney Duncan
feed.subtitle: The recent Survivor: South Pacific outcasts speak to Dose.ca about compromising their religious morals, dealing with Coach's manipulation tactics and feeling bad for Cochran.

entry.title: Survivor Interview: Dawn Meehan and Whitney Duncan

link.title: Survivor Interview: Stacey Powell

link.Abstract: Not even being a gay Christian retired New York City cop with a daughter could save the 48 year-old from becoming the second player eliminated from the Samoan Island.
link.title: Survivor Interview: Mark "Papa Bear" Caruso

content.div:
As Survivor: South Pacific's only remaining loyal members of the former Savaii tribe at the merged Te Tuna camp, English teacher Dawn Meehan and country music singer Whitney Duncan were the two obvious choices to be sent to Redemption Island by the overpowering former Upolu tribe and their recruited turncoat, Harvard law student John Cochran. Soon after the two were eliminated permanently by their former leader, Ozzy, they enjoyed their own brand of schadenfreude when Cochran's ‘big move' proved all for not and he was sent packing to Redemption Island, leaving only the former Upolu (and their spiritual leader, Coach) still in the actual game -- though Ozzy and Cochran still have a chance to return from banishment. Now safely in their hometowns of Salt Lake City and Nashville, respectively, Meehan and Duncan spoke to Dose.ca about compromising their religious morals, dealing with Coach's manipulation tactics and feeling bad for Cochran.

Dawn, you are a proud Mormon and made a big deal at the beginning of the game about not swimming in your underwear because you felt it betrayed your religious ideals. Do you feel you compromised your beliefs in the game?

Meehan: I think it's a game that requires compromising. I do think I went into it thinking this is like being Alice in Wonderland going down the rabbit hole. You're going to come out of it; it's a game. So I think the behavior in the game doesn't really have to be consistent with your life outside of it. It really is a game. If I'm playing football I'm going to tackle people; I don't do that in my real life. So when I went into it I tried really hard to give myself permission to play like a kid. And I think I got to see that. When we voted out Elyse that was planned. It wasn't kind to vote her out, she didn't know – and I really liked Elyse – but it's part of the game.

How about you Whitney? As a Christian, you do you feel you compromised your morals on Survivor?

Duncan: I definitely prayed a lot out there I just didn't make a spectacle of it. And I felt the people that did, like Coach, were really using [prayer] to manipulate people. That kind of stuff, real life or game, comes off to me as creepy. But it is a game: there's lying, there's deceiving, there's betraying, that's the game of Survivor. It's nice to go in thinking you're not going to lie to anybody but when you're put in that position you realize this is a game for a million dollars; it's not black and white. There's a lot of grey in there. At the end of the day your family knows who you are and that's all that matters.

In our interview last week, both Jim and Keith said they felt Coach was running his tribe like a cult. Do you agree with that?

Duncan: I agree with that. If you were there on the beach you'd understand. Everyone's scared to make a move. It's like they're going against him because he's made them believe that Survivor is going to affect their life after the game.

Meehan: That's it. The thing that works for Coach is he takes his previous game experience and says, "The game affected me negatively in society. It affected my employment; it affected my family because I was portrayed negatively." So he comes into the game and he's able to leverage that and play on people's fears. He tells them, "If you play this game and are duplicitous -- if you say you're going to vote with us and you vote otherwise -- America, or Canada, is going to see you a certain way and it's going to affect your life." He goes to extremes to play on that fear and that works. It's working on Brendan, it's working on Edna. To me that's where he's a master at manipulation. It works for him.

As you saw, and no doubt took great pleasure in, Cochran's ‘big move' – which more or less directly led to the elimination of the entire Savaii tribe -- ended up backfiring on him. Do you respect him or hate him?

Duncan: I wouldn't go with either of those. I certainly don't respect him. He said it best: he said that if his move doesn't get repaid it will go down as one of the most idiotic moves in Survivor history. And he admitted that he was actually humiliated because he was so duped. I actually feel bad for him because he was so gullible and really bought in to Coach's BS. I don't hold a grudge against him but I also don't respect his gameplay because it actually worsened his game. A move helps your game; his move destroyed his game.

Meehan: It destroyed all of our game.

If you had the chance, what would you have done differently?

Meehan: I've thought about whether I should have given Cochrane my immunity and we would have had six (Upolu members) versus six (Savaii members) votes. If I had drawn a rock if he would have stayed loyal to Savaii? It's something I've thought about a lot. I think he would have stayed with us if we would have become the majority at that that point but I'm not sure he would have stayed loyal to Savaii. That's my feeling.

Whitney: I think he wanted to create a character and make a big move. So he made his big move, he just didn't follow it up with anything.

Finally, who do you think will win the game?

Meehan: I hope Ozzy.

Duncan: I hope Ozzy, too. He's really Savaii's last hope. Well, not last hope but I don't consider Cochran a part of Savaii.
